contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2009}}The '''Web-based Inquiry Science Environment''' ('''WISE''') is a program hosted by [[Berkeley University]] and supported by the [[National Science Foundation]]. It provides a platform for creating [[inquiry-based science]] projects for middle school and high school students to work collaboratively using evidence and resources from the Web. WISE inquiry projects are typically developed by teams including teachers, researchers, and scientists. These projects range in duration from 2 days to 4 weeks, suitable for teachers in every science topic at all grade levels. The use of Internet materials provides the foundation of WISE. All projects make use of some content from the World Wide Web, as well as additional Web pages authored for purposes of the project. This approach helps students learn to use the Internet for inquiry, critiquing Web sites, designing approaches, or comparing arguments. Typical projects engage students in designing solutions to problems (e.g. building a desert house that is warm at night and cool during the day), debating contemporary science controversies (e.g. the causes of declining amphibian populations), investigating scientific phenomena (e.g. thermal equilibrium in the classroom), or critiquing scientific claims found in web sites (e.g. arguments for life on Mars).
WISE projects can also incorporate [[Java (programming language)|Java]] applets, flash models, forums to facilitate online discussions, data collection, drawing, argument creation, resource sharing, branching, concept mapping and other built-in components. WISE is entirely browser-based, meaning that students only need access to a computer with an Internet connection, with no required software other than the Web browser). All student work is saved on central project servers that enable student accounts and teacher accounts to be coordinated, with special Web environments designed to support teachers and students. Students can access their work from any computer on the Internet. Teachers can choose from the library of curriculum projects in the WISE Teacher's Portal, each accompanied by a set of materials including a detailed lesson plan, pre and post assessments, connections to the AAAS National standards, tools for setting up a custom grading scheme, and even a software tool that enables customization of the WISE project for local issues, geographical features or student populations. Teachers can monitor and grade student work in real time, provide formative feedback during a project run, and manage their student accounts.
Finally, WISE provides a user-friendly interface to facilitate the authoring of new projects, with numerous technology-based components including online discussions, data collection, drawing, argument creation, resource sharing, concept mapping and other built-in tools. Developers can also include custom tools of their own design. Projects are further customizable by teachers and other end users through the same interface to better meet the needs of their students and constraints of local educational settings. The website provides rich descriptions of the WISE learning environment, a library of inquiry projects for students and teachers, a teacher support center, and the complete authoring environment.
==External links== * [http://wise2.berkeley.edu WISE2 website] * [http://wise.berkeley.edu WISE4 website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Web-Based Inquiry Science Environment}} [[Category:Educational projects]] [[Category:Applied learning]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Young Ones | image = Young Ones poster.jpg | alt = Teaser poster | caption = Teaser poster | director = [[Jake Paltrow]] | producer = {{plainlist| * Michael Auret * Tristan Lynch * Jake Paltrow }} | writer = Jake Paltrow | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Nicholas Hoult]] * [[Elle Fanning]] * [[Michael Shannon]] * [[Kodi Smit-McPhee]] }} | music = [[Nathan Johnson (musician)|Nathan Johnson]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Nathan Johnson Tumblr post|url=http://nathanjohnson.tumblr.com/post/98913112664/my-score-for-the-upcoming-young-ones-is-now|accessdate=October 14, 2014}}</ref> | cinematography = [[Giles Nuttgens]] | editing = Matt Mayer | studio = {{plainlist| * Subotica Entertainment * Spier Films }} | distributor = [[Screen Media Films]] | released = {{Film date|2014|01|18|[[Sundance Film Festival]]|2014|10|17|United States}} | runtime = 100 minutes | country = {{plainlist| * South Africa * Ireland<ref name="iftn">{{cite news|title=Irish-South African Co-Production ‘Young Ones’ Begins Filming|url=http://www.iftn.ie/news/?act1=record&aid=73&rid=4285779&tpl=archnews&force=1|accessdate=15 August 2013|newspaper=iftn.ie|date=12 February 2013}}</ref> }} | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Young Ones''''' (UK title '''''Bad Land: Road to Fury''''') is a 2014 [[action film|action]] [[science fiction film]] directed and written by [[Jake Paltrow]]. The film stars [[Nicholas Hoult]], [[Elle Fanning]], [[Michael Shannon]] and [[Kodi Smit-McPhee]]. The film had its world premiere at [[2014 Sundance Film Festival]] on January 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sundance 2014: World Cinema Dramatic Competition|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/sundance-2014-world-cinema-dramatic-competition|accessdate=May 5, 2014}}</ref> The film was released on October 17, 2014 in the United States.
==Plot== In a post-drought apocalypse United States, people kill for water. Ernest Holm lives with his son Jerome and daughter Mary in their small townhouse and field. His wife has been involved in an accident earlier and is now permanently hospitalized in a facility where she can walk while wired to a special frame. While everyone else has left the area, Ernest and his family remain, as Ernest believes that the land will grow once more if only there is irrigation. Ernest gets water for his family by delivering supplies to the "water men" who extract water from deep wells through a government deal. When his mule breaks its legs and he has to kill it, Ernest goes to Sam Lever's auction house and buys a robotic carrier machine called Simulit Shadow ("Sim") to replace it, beating the offers of Flem Lever, Sam's son, a young, troubled man who has been seeing Mary without Ernest's consent.
One morning, Ernest finds the Sim is missing, and he goes looking for it. When he gets to the water men, he is accused of stealing their supplies. He finds Flem transporting the stolen supplies with the Sim; Flem plans to sell them at the border. Ernest takes Flem captive, ties him to the machine, and aims to take the supplies back to the water men. When they stop due to dehydration, Flem convinces Ernest to rehydrate with the liquor they are transporting. Wanting to escape, Flem throws a stone at Ernest's head and [[frame-up|frames]] the machine for Ernest's death.
Flem marries Mary after helping the family obtain illegal irrigation from the water men, thus saving their farm, which was originally Flem's father's. But after finding out Ernest had overwhelming debts to repay to a bank, which is now going to repossess the farm, Flem tricks his friend Robbie into selling his baby behind his wife's back. Robbie is killed and the Sim is lost in an altercation with the buyers. However, the machine returns limping and mangled to its manufacturer, who resides in a city across the border. The owner, Calvin Hooyman, reaches Jerome at the Holm residence via CB radio, informing him about the machine.
Jerome crosses the border with the help of Anna, a girl who lives with the "settlers", people fighting back against the government's regulations and considered terrorists. Jerome meets Calvin, who gives the repaired Sim back to him, and shows Jerome how the machine's laser sensor behaves like a rudimentary video recorder. Jerome plays the recording and finds the truth about Ernest's death. Arriving home before Flem, Jerome questions him as to how the machine found its way home, since Flem claimed to have sold it in order to repay the debt. Flem's lies only infuriate Jerome more, but at first he takes no action. Instead, he lures Flem out in the desert by posing as Robbie via radio and letters, ultimately causing Flem to fall into a pit trap and break his legs. As Flem cries for help, Jerome, who has been secretly following him, comes at the pit's mouth. Flem realizes that Jerome knows about what happened to Ernest. He tries to elicit Jerome's mercy, but Jerome coldly shoots him in the head. Jerome ultimately decides to withhold these events and the circumstances of Ernest's death from Mary, who is pregnant with Flem's child. Brother and sister remain in the house, planning to bring their mother there from the hospital now that they can pay for her brace wires, and wishing the baby will be a girl.
The film is divided into three chapters, named after the main character in each of them: "Ernest Holm", "Flem Lever", and "Jerome Holm", respectively.
==Cast== * [[Michael Shannon]] as Ernest Holm * [[Nicholas Hoult]] as Flem Lever * [[Elle Fanning]] as Mary Holm * [[Kodi Smit-McPhee]] as Jerome Holm * [[Robert Hobbs]] as Caleb Moore * [[David Butler (actor)|David Butler]] as Sam Lever * [[Aimee Mullins]] as Katherine Holm * [[Christy Pankhurst]] as Robbie * [[Alex McGregor (actress)|Alex McGregor]] as Sooz * [[David Clatworthy]] as Calvin Hooyman * [[Liah O'Prey]] as Anna
==Production== [[Nicholas Hoult]], [[Elle Fanning]], [[Michael Shannon]] and [[Kodi Smit-McPhee]] joined the cast on February 7, 2013.<ref name="Nicholas">{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/nicholas-hoult-michael-shannon-and-elle-fanning-to-star-in-young-ones-1118065854/ |title=Nicholas Hoult, Michael Shannon and Elle Fanning to star in ‘Young Ones’ |first=John |last=Hopewell |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=2013-02-07 |accessdate=2017-12-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2013/michael-shannon-nicholas-hoult-two-more-join-young-ones-sci-fi/ |title=Michael Shannon, Nicholas Hoult & Two More Join 'Young Ones' Sci-Fi |first=Ethan |last=Anderton |website=firstshowing.net (sourced from [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]) |date=2013-02-08 |accessdate=2017-12-10}}</ref> [[Giles Nuttgens]] is the director of photography while Tristan Lynch and Michael Auret are the producers.<ref name=Nicholas/> On May 13, 2014 [[Screen Media Films]] acquired the U.S. rights to the film.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/05/young-ones-jake-paltrow-screen-media/ |title=Screen Media Springs For Jake Paltrow-Helmed Sci-Fi ‘Young Ones’ |first=Jen |last=Yamato |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=2014-05-13 |accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref>
===Filming=== The shooting of the film began in February 2013 at [[Namaqualand]], [[Northern Cape]], South Africa and shot until March 15.<ref name="iftn" />
==Marketing== The first trailer was released on July 6, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Billington|first1=Alex|title=Indie Trailer Sunday: Director Jake Paltrow's New Sci-Fi 'Young Ones'|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2014/indie-trailer-sunday-director-jake-paltrows-new-sci-fi-young-ones/|accessdate=July 7, 2014|publisher=firstshowing.net|date=July 6, 2014}}</ref> Another U.S. trailer was released on July 23.<ref name=2nd>{{cite news|last1=Buchanan|first1=Kyle|title=See the Visually Striking Trailer for Young Ones, With Michael Shannon and Elle Fanning|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/07/young-ones-trailer-elle-fanning-nicholas-hoult.html|accessdate=July 23, 2014|publisher=vulture.com|date=July 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Release== The film was released on October 17, 2014 in the United States.<ref name="2nd" />
==Reception== [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], reports that 43% of 30 surveyed critics gave the film a positive review; the average rating is 5.3/10. The critical consensus states: "Visually compelling but narratively barren, ''Young Ones'' adds little to the dystopian Western genre."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/young_ones_2014/|title=Young Ones (2014)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> [[Metacritic]] rated it 47/100 based on 13 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/young-ones|title=Young Ones|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> Geoff Berkshire of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote, "Jake Paltrow's visually rich, dramatically spare sci-fi Western bogs down in its primal tale of murder and revenge."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/sundance-film-review-young-ones-1201064630/|title=Sundance Film Review: 'Young Ones'|last=Berkshire|first=Geoff|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 19, 2014|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> David Rooney of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' wrote, "There's little refreshment on offer in this parched lo-fi sci-fi drama, despite the distinctive element of its retro rural setting."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/young-sundance-review-672392|title=Young Ones: Sundance Review|last=Rooney|first=David|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 19, 2014|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> Jeannette Catsoulis of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called it a "spare but potent melodrama" that focuses on male violence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/17/arts/the-sci-fi-film-young-ones-stars-michael-shannon.html|title=The Future Is Bright, and Hot|last=Catsoulis|first=Jeannette|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 16, 2014|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> Robert Abele of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that it "gets lost amid a mishmash of film styles".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-young-ones-movie-review-20141017-story.html|title=Review 'Young Ones' wastes intriguing dire-future premise|last=Abele|first=Robert|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=October 16, 2014|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
